Author: zack#6467
Content:
Amoveo is the only project trying to resuse Nakamoto consensus for the oracle.
It is a radical departure from existing oracle designs, and you are right to question whether it will work.

But if it does work, it will be vastly cheaper than the alternatives.

Content: so... "hard update"s?

Author: zack#6467
Content: the nash equilibrium is that we will never have to hard update to prevent an oracle from closing the wrong way.

Author: zack#6467
Content:
There has been some planning to add a feature to the full node, so that you could manually tell it to never download blocks that close a particular oracle in a way that you specify as lying.
I think it is a good idea, we should probably add this feature.

Author: zack#6467
Content: @smk762 -  dracocanis ominator  an oracle in Amoveo is an on-chain data structure. it doesn't own money. it cannot bet.

Author: smk762 -  dracocanis ominator#7640

Author: zack#6467
Content: aggregating data feeds cannot be a secure oracle.

Author: jl777c#5810

Author: jl777c#5810

Author: zack#6467
Content:
no amount of logic can combine data feeds into a secure oracle.
You at least need the data feeds to be commit-reveal, then it might be possible.

Author: zack#6467
Content: and you probably need to have the reporters have some vested interest. a bond or something.

Author: zack#6467
Content:
you need tires to drive a car, but you can't put a tire in the driver's seat and let him drive.
You need an oracle to do betting, but the oracle itself is not making any bets.

Author: zack#6467
Content:
@jl777c  yeah, that is the basics of what Augur and Bitcoin Hivemind do. you can can look at the bitcoin hivemind docs for the details.

Personally, I think Amoveo's oracle will be much more successful of a design.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, so what if there is a commit/reveal process for each data point and the datafees are given to the ones with the highest correlation to the others

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: make the game theory so the data providers make the most money by having the most accurate data

Author: jl777c#5810

Author: zack#6467
Content: yeah, that would be closer to a working solution. But I still recommend to read some other people's designs before building anything.

Author: jl777c#5810

Author: zack#6467
Content: There is a limit in Augur where the total amount of money being bet needs to be worth significantly less than the value of the votecoins staked in the oracles

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: first reporter of bad data gets the most bounty and if it really is a valid bug, it overrides the data. the stake holders would vote on the validity of the bug report

Author: zack#6467
Content: it makes their design so expensive. they have to pay big fees to votecoin holders to keep the price high enough

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: by letting anybody gain bug bounty for bad data, it would make people run data gather/compare code to be the first to find any bad data

Author: jl777c#5810

Author: zack#6467
Content:
A lot of oracle mechanisms involve escalation mechanisms.
So if someone is trying to push bad data through, there is a way for honest people to lock up money in a deposit to mark that data as bad, and needing further review.

Content:
`by letting anybody gain bug bounty for bad data, it would make people run data gather/compare code to be the first to find any bad data`

Author: zack#6467
Content: Oracles are a deep subject, it would probably take a long time to be able to build a new secure one, but copying or modifying an existing design would be faster.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, I understand, this is why there is no bet CC yet

Author: jl777c#5810

Author: zack#6467
Content: I would be honored if you grouped an Amoveo light node with one of your komodo chains, so that you could make bets who's outcome is determined by Amoveo's oracle.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we would just need to make an oracles CC that cross posted from the amoveo chain

Author: zack#6467
Content: that wouldn't be cryptoeconomically secure. you would be trusting someone.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but we can do it with merkleproofs

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: to avoid trusting anyone

Author: zack#6467
Content: yes, Amoveo's data structure is fully merkelized, and the light node uses headers to verify the merkel proofs

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so why wouldnt that work?

Author: zack#6467
Content: why wouldn't what work?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: "that wouldn't be cryptoeconomically secure. you would be trusting someone."

Author: zack#6467
Content: oh, the oracle CC module as specified is a trusted feed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: would need to query enough SPV servers to verify the merkle root can be used

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this is the purpose of the oracles CC, to get data that is otherwise inaccessible onchain, so the merkle proof can be put onchain and then the betCC can query SPV servers to validate the merkleproof

Author: zack#6467
Content:
you should run the light node, so you can verify headers and know that the merkle root you are looking at is valid.

An attacker can spin up hundreds of fake spv nodes easily.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, light node then

Author: zack#6467
Content: if you run a light node, then you don't need the oracle CC. the light node will verify whatever merkel proof you need

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: instead of having the data offchain and ephemereal, the oracles CC would get it onchain so it is right there for other CC to access

Author: zack#6467
Content: so you want to re-write an amoveo light node on-chain on komodo? that is ambitious

Author: zack#6467
Content: just having each full node be required to also run an Amoveo light node is good enough

Author: zack#6467
Content: komodo has lots of chains, right? it is like a network of blockchains?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, many chains

Author: zack#6467
Content: so you can attach a light node to one of the chains, so every full node of that chain needs an amoveo light node

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, that would be similar to our dual-daemon functionality

Author: zack#6467
Content: then you would have access to a very cheap oracle that is very likely to be secure
